thread.title: 'This just isn't good enough': GOP slams Obama on jobs
thread.title_full: 'This just isn't good enough': GOP slams Obama on jobs | Washington Examiner

author: Joseph Lawler
title: 'This just isn't good enough': GOP slams Obama on jobs
text:
Congressional Republicans wasted no time in criticizing President Obama's track record on economic growth following the release of a jobs report Friday that fell well short of economist's expectations.
"Too many middle-class families are still struggling in this economy, and we can do a lot better," House Speaker John Boehner, R-Ohio, said in a statement following the news that the economy added just 142,000 jobs in September.
"Moreover, there is no excuse for the president to continue pushing an agenda that will hurt hardworking families and stifle economic growth," Boehner added, mentioning in particular the president's new rule on ozone emissions announced this week.
It is routine for the opposition party to take potshots at the president in the wake of bad economic news. Friday's report, which also showed job growth for July and August revised down by a combined 59,000, created an extra opening for such criticism.
  Congressman Stephen Fincher: From Tea Partier to corporate welfare champion It would be an understatement to say Fincher has come to terms with boondoggles and special interests.
By Timothy P. Carney • 10/02/15 9:49 AM "This just isn't good enough. Flat wages, weak job growth, and far too many people simply giving up," said Paul Ryan, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee and the party's most influential voice on domestic policy matters. "This recovery continues to disappoint, but we can't accept it as the new normal."
The Wisconsin Republican called for a rewrite of the tax code, finishing trade agreements, and safety-net reform to boost growth.
"While job openings are increasing, hiring is slow and layoffs are on the rise," said Sen. Dan Coats of Indiana, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee. "This all points to an uncertain and apprehensive trajectory for the U.S. economy."
Private-sector economists had expected slightly more than 200,000 new jobs for September, and many analysts had anticipated that August's initially reported 173,000 new jobs would be revised up.
Instead, job growth in both months was found to be weaker than previously estimated. August's revised gains were only 136,000.
Also from the Washington Examiner Job growth disappoints at 142,000 in September, unemployment rate 5.1 percent Following August's disappointing 173k mark, economists had expected a rebound to 203k new payroll jobs.
By Joseph Lawler • 10/02/15 8:31 AM Nevertheless, the longer-term trend is toward lower unemployment. At 5.1 percent in September, the unemployment rate is almost half of the 10 percent recession peak in 2009. Monthly job growth above 100,000 is sufficient to keep the unemployment rate headed down, according to researchers at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
In a statement on the report, White House economic adviser Jason Furman blamed the weak report on slowing growth overseas and "global financial turmoil."
He noted that the private-sector has added 13.2 million jobs over 67 straight months of job growth, which is the longest such streak on record.
"Given the increased uncertainty around the world, it is imperative that the United States not further exacerbate that uncertainty with unnecessary brinksmanship and austerity," Furman said, in a challenge to the GOP-led Congress that will soon have to negotiate a spending agreement and an increase in the debt ceiling.
He called specifically for Congress to increase spending above the statutory across-the-board limits currently in place, and to re-authorize the Export-Import Bank, which saw its charter expire at the end of June.
Also from the Washington Examiner Vatican: Pope's meeting not a full endorsement of Kim Davis Pope Francis' "only real audience" during his U.S. visit was with one of his former students and his family.
By Barbara Boland • 10/02/15 9:17 AM
